Award.AwardTitle: Chemical Triggers for Spin-State Switching: Discovery and Control of Switching Mechanisms
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamic & Mechanism B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Matthew Shores of the Department of Chemistry at Colorado State University (CSU) is exploring new classes of transition metal complexes that can serve as molecular switches. The goal of the research is to understand how host-guest interactions alter the structure of coordination complexes and change their magnetic properties. These results will inform design principles for the development of chemical sensors, switchable molecular magnets, and magnetic resonance contrast agents. The project combines several synthetic, measurement and computational techniques to provide diverse training for the research students involved. Interactions with the CSU Chemistry Research Experiences for Undergraduates program and collaborations with researchers at CSU-Pueblo aim to broaden participation from underrepresented groups. The group's expertise in magnetic measurements and data interpretation will promote discovery via several ongoing and new magnetic collaborations with inorganic and materials chemistry research groups around the country.

Complexes that can exist in and reliably switch between two well-defined magnetic states offer the possibility for functional materials development at the nano- and molecular length scales. The proposed research aims to enhance magnetic property switching in transition metal complexes by controlling local geometry and ligand field effects via outer sphere, non-covalent interactions with guest molecules. Specific research goals for this project are: (1) computational understanding of thermodynamics and distortion pathways in magnetic-state switching, toward predictive models; (2) exploration of new chemical triggers and new ions for guest-dependent spin-state switching complexes; and (3) external control of axial magnetic anisotropy in Co(II) single-molecule magnet complexes. The ultimate aim is to gain new understanding in the design of novel mechanisms for magnetic property switching, and contribute new sensing architectures relevant to chemical sensing and molecular imaging applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamic & Mechanism B Program of the Chemistry Division, the research group of Professor Matthew Shores of the Department of Chemistry at Colorado State University explored new classes of transition metal complexes that can serve as molecular switches. The goal of the research was to improve understanding of the ways in which host-guest interactions change the magnetic properties of these molecular switches. The project combined several synthetic, measurement and computational techniques to provide diverse training for the research students involved.

In collaboration with Professor Rappe at CSU, the group developed computational methods for connecting magnetic property changes to the electronic structures of the molecular switching complexes, and for more accurate accounting of the interactions between molecular switches and their local environments. These results will inform design principles for the development of chemical sensors, switchable molecular magnets, and magnetic resonance contrast agents.

The group discovered that the spin state properties of certain complexes containing iron could be modified in solution by modifying the already-bound ligands. Besides the interesting changes in magnetism observed, the metal-mediated synthetic chemistry developed here offers access to ligands that cannot be prepared directly.

New complexes containing iron, cobalt and nickel were prepared and studied for magnetic switching properties.

In collaboration with researchers at CSU-Pueblo, hybrid materials where cobalt complexes were woven into cellulose matrices were characterized; these materials have the potential to signal the presence of cyanide through visible color changes.

Multiple collaborations with researchers in the U.S. and abroad were established and/or supported to measure the magnetic properties of inorganic compounds with novel structures and/or metal ions. Many synthetic chemists do not have access to sensitive magnetic property measurement instrumentation, so these studies promote deeper understanding of the properties of inorganic compounds and materials. In this grant cycle, the Shores group collaborated with at least 11 research groups in new work and/or publication of results.

This project supported research efforts for 3 graduate students. The junior researchers were trained in air- and moisture-sensitive inorganic synthesis techniques, X-ray crystallography, spectroscopic characterization methods, and magnetometry. The PI and research group also contributed to the mentoring and professional development activities of the long-running CSU Chemistry REU program. The results from this project were disseminated in several papers (with several manuscripts in preparation) and through student and PI presentations at multiple seminars, including one international meeting. One Ph.D. degree was awarded for work completed in this project. The project strengthened an ongoing theory-experiment collaboration at CSU, and research results generated in the project were incorporated into the tutorial and (under)graduate chemistry course materials. The project also partially supported the visiting and sample measurements of two undergraduate students from the CSU Pueblo as one of group's collaborative efforts.
